1081593853281415168.text: Another big pro for gaming: it is active learning and learning is best done through direct experience. Compare to listening to a teacher lecture, reading a book, or watching a video (all passive learning by default).

1079428936386445313.text: A lot of this learning will probably happen in games. They're great testing grounds because they establish real value for items (there's skin in the game) while making the cost of failure feel low (developers and players can take more risk and try to break systems).

- Cost of creating a new crypto system near 0 vs. nearly impossible to start a new government or central bank

1053175236617691136.text:
Debate will continue to rage on whether or not the gaming trend is good for society. But a few things are clear to me:
- It's growing fast with no sign of reversal
- I've experienced life-changing benefits
- Crypto will take it to a whole new level by making these economies real

1053174986620338176.text: I learned as much about logic, spatial reasoning, and physics from virtual worlds (especially CAD software) as I did from school. Portal 2 has been used in multiple studies to show dramatic boosts in cognitive abilities; perhaps even more than traditional schooling.

1053174905678622720.text: Video games taught me what is required for excellence. I worked incredibly hard to eventually lead the best team in the world at a small game (America's Army) in 2005 and that experience has helped set my internal bar ever since.

1053165980459839488.text: Modding is a beautiful thing. It's an incredible outlet for hands on learning and creativity in a world where traditional education is becoming less relevant and young people are increasingly struggling to find purpose.

1053163377504047104.text: These games can start by looking deceptively simple. In some cases they may not explicitly even be a "game" (see http://reddit.com/r/place ). But simple building blocks quickly give way to complicated emergent behavior. Said another way: fun and deep gameplay!

1053162514660286469.text: Why? The building blocks are more likely to be open and thus stackable. Want to create the biggest game out there? Create the most attractive one to extend! Perhaps the best future business model for future video games is creating a platform.

1053160748338167810.text: Crypto supercharges gaming modding culture: the lifeblood of the gaming industry since 1998.

1053159606829047808.text: The extensibility point is key. Games are built on modding culture. Counter Strike and Team Fortress were mods (aka forks) of Half Life. League of Legends copied DOTA which was a mod of Warcraft 3. Fortnite copied PUBG, a mod of DayZ: Battle Royale, which was a mod of ARMA2.

1053157411542855680.text: The trajectory is clear: more people are playing games, their economies are getting bigger, the closed economies of these games hurt both trust and extensibility (see https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/general-discussion/cRJfwuYi-the-league-of-legend-economy-is-ludicrous …), and crypto will make these economies open.

1053156165889142784.text: Yet we've also come quite far. In 2005 the largest prize pool in a year for a game was $500k (Painkiller). In 2019 it will be $100 million (Fortnite), with the winning team of a single tournament in 2018 taking home $11 million (DOTA 2's The International).

1053153819331182592.text: In 2006 I sold my high end World of Warcraft account for $2,500. I spent 3,000 hours playing. That's $0.87 an hour .

1053147855861366784.text: I suspect blockchain-based digital assets will make virtual economies very real. People will be able to earn their entire living in virtual worlds in the next 10-15 years, changing the definition of “work” itself.

1053147855102238721.text: The optimistic view: this is a rapidly growing new frontier offering lots of opportunity, it just happens to be digital rather than physical (ex: space).

8a/ Implications:
- Curation Markets provide a way to directly bet on algorithms. Since a lot of curators will be algorithms and people will seek returns from staking, they'll delegate their stakes to the best performing algorithms.

958388815118258176.text: 7/ More complicated mechanisms can be layered on top, including voting systems to approve/deny new members to join a community (Token Curated Registries), different formulas for monetary policies, and incentives to hold tokens for longer.

958388812232540160.text: 6b/ - Feed takeover. What if someone buys a bunch of tokens to advertise irrelevant content? Likely answer: they'd destroy the value of what they just bought, making such an attack less likely. Could also require further staking.

958388811427299328.text:
6a/ Challenges:
- Tragedy of the commons. How do you get people to be put work into curation beyond their vested interest in seeing their tokens go up? Likely answer: reward those who curate first/early. See "Freshness Bonus":https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WtEae919D0izMUlBgw08aY1Ep6vgybguPKNY7tQWruE/edit …

958388810680684544.text:
5/ Applications:
- Decentralized reddit

958388809699180544.text: 4c/ For example, if the monetary policy algorithm is "increase the price by 1 ETH per token outstanding", 1st token can be bought for 1 ETH, the 10th token for 10 ETH. If I'm the 5th person in I buy for 5 ETH, if community grows to 100 I can sell back to the contract for 100 ETH.

958388808977821697.text: 4b/ The central bank has an algorithmic monetary policy. Tokens get more expensive as more are created. Anyone can sell their stake back to the smart contract for ETH at current rates at any time, ETH returned comes from the treasury.

958388808222883840.text: 4a/ Mechanics: token holders get to vote on/stake the content of a feed in proportion to the amount of tokens they own. A smart contract acts as the central bank for the feed's tokens. Tokens are purchased for ETH from the contract and are stored in a treasury.

958388807392378880.text: 3/ A lot of life comes down to effective information processing. Specifically, creating ranked lists. They are the root of decision making: consider options, rank them, take action. Curation markets can do this on an arbitrary number of topics. Potential scope is huge.

958388804544471041.text: 2/ Core idea: the token holders of the feed have an incentive to create the best feed possible to attract as much attention as possible. More attention --> more valuable feed tokens because of their value to others who want their content in the feed.

958388803655184386.text: 1/ Token curation markets use economic incentives to create crowd curated information feeds/lists on any topic. 3c/ Inflation funding (cont.)
Upsides: Very large potential bounties, flexible rate of funding, continuous funding source, decentralized.
Downsides: complicated, hard to prevent gaming of the system.

949355741160206336.text:
3c/ Inflation funding.
Anyone can submit improvements. Token holders vote to approve/reject and decide bounty size. New tokens are minted to pay bounty.
Examples: Tezos, DFINITY (neither live)

949355740333973504.text:
3b/ Foundation funded continuously by network activity.
Example: Decred. 10% of block rewards go to development fund, with staked voting on proposals for the fund.
Upsides: continuous funding source, decentralized.
Downsides: inflexible rate of funding.

949355739037941760.text:
3a/ Foundation funded by one time allocation in token sale.
Foundation pays salaries and/or open bounties. Can be centralized (most common today) or decentralized.
Example: Ethereum.
Upsides: simple, expert curation in early days.
Downsides: limited bounties, runs out eventually.
